Appendix Table 4. Treatment Effects on Asset Values (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) Coef. (S.E.) Control Mean Control S.D. Obs. [1] Total asset value (PPP$) 290.15*** (66.97) 743.56 922.05 874 [2] Household durables (PPP$) 64.16* (33.13) 406.32 481.52 874 [3] Productive capital (PPP$) 227.52*** (42.25) 306.01 579.22 874 [4] Ag. tools & structures (PPP$) 30.81** (14.61) 82.17 220.88 874 [5] Livestock (PPP$) 195.37*** (35.17) 219.75 462.39 874 [6] Goats and sheep (PPP$) 195.89*** (30.78) 149.76 358.23 874

Notes: The main assets that were given out as part of the program were livestock (75%). The second most common asset was start-up capital or assets for small businesses but the endline survey did not include information about enterprise assets. Thus, the two asset categories "household durables" and "Ag. tools & structures" mostly closely map into "asset types not part of the program". For simplicity of presentation we include five items as part of household durables that could not readily be classified as a household durable or productive asset. The mean of these "other" items is PPP$87.76 and the results are qualitatively unchanged when classifying them as part of a separate category. Variables are top winsorized at the 99th percentile. * denotes statistical significance at the 10-percent level; ** at the 5percent level; and *** at the 1-percent level.

Appendix Table 8. Treatment Effects on Food Security (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) Coef. (S.E.) Control Mean Control S.D. Obs. [1] Food security index 0.04 (0.07) -0.00 1.00 874 [2] All household members usually get enough food 0.01 (0.03) 0.47 0.50 862 [3] Everyone regularly eats 2+ meals a day 0.03 (0.02) 0.89 0.31 874 [4] Adults did not cut or skip meals in past 12m 0.02 (0.03) 0.46 0.50 871 [5] Adults did not skip eating for a full days in past 12m -0.01 (0.03) 0.80 0.40 871 [6] Kids did not cut or skip meals in past 12m 0.01 (0.04) 0.56 0.50 649

Notes: The dependent variable of row 1, "Food security index", is a normalized average of the normalized transformations of rows 2-6, with normalization referring to substracting the control group mean and dividing by the standard deviation of the control group. Dependent variables in rows 2-6 are binary indicators. The dep. var. of row 2, "All household members usually get enough food", is based on the question "How often do all members of your household not get enough food to eat?" and is coded as 1 if the response was not one of the prompted options that ranged from "Daily" to "Yearly", and 0 otherwise. The dep. var. of row 3, "Everyone regularly eats 2+ meals a day", is based on the question "Does everyone in the household regularly eat at least two meals a day? " and is coded as 1 if the response to the latter question was "Yes", and 0 otherwise. The dep. var. of row 4, "Adults did not cut or skip meals in past 12m", is based on the question "In the last 12 months, did you or any other adults in your household ever cut the size of your meals or skip meals because there were not enough resources for food?" and is coded as 1 if the response to the latter question was "No", and 0 otherwise. The dep. var. of row 5, "Adults did not skip eating for a full days in past 12m", is based on the question "In the last 12 months, did you or any other adults in your household ever not eat for a whole day because there wasn't enough money for food?" and is coded as 1 if the response to the latter question was "No", and 0 otherwise. The dep. var. of row 6, "Kids did not skip eating for a full days in past 12m", is based on the question "In the last 12 months, did a household member younger than 18 ever cut the size of the meals or ever skip a meal because there wasn't enough money for food?" and is coded as 1 if the response to the latter question was "No", and 0 otherwise. Variables are top winsorized at the 99th percentile. * denotes statistical significance at the 10-percent level; ** at the 5-percent level; and *** at the 1-percent level.

Appendix Notes: "Hh" = household. This table repeats the analysis of Table 3 with inverse probability weighted observations, with weights based the likelihood of being surveyed at endline by recertification status as well as the predicted likelihood of being surveyed using the baseline variables of Tables 1, 2 and 3. See Table 2 for additional details. * denotes statistical significance at the 10-percent level; ** at the 5percent level; and *** at the 1-percent level. For additional notes, see Table 3.

figure.figDesc: Randomization was stratified by village. Column 4 shows p-values based on regressions of each baseline variable on the treatment indicator and a full set of village indicators. The joint test for orthogonality is based on regression of the treatment indicator on all baseline variables and village indicators. Variables are top winsorized at the 99th percentile.

div.head: Variable Definition Appendix
div.p: This appendix summarizes key outcome variables in the study and provides additional detail on how we constructed them.

div.head: Endline Variables
div.p: Key Welfare Outcomes (Table )
• Total Asset Value (PPP$) Sum of durable and livestock assets owned at endline.

• Monthly Consumption per Capita (PPP$) Total consumption per-capita includes spending on education, health, non-food consumables, and durable goods, as well as calculated value of food consumption. The resulting sum is scaled to reflect monthly consumption at the household level. This is then divided by the number of adult equivalents in the household at the time of survey to produce a per-capita statistic.

• Monthly Consumption per Household (PPP$) Total consumption includes spending on education, health, non-food consumibles, and durable goods, as well as calculated value of food consumption. The components are summed and scaled to one months equivalents.

• Total Income, Past m (PPP$) Each household respondent with income reported their regular and irregular sources of income. For regular income, respondents provided monthly income, which was multiplied by months to get an annual total. For irregular income, respondents provided minimum and maximum monthly income and the number of months they earned at each rate. Minimum and maximum monthly income were multiplied by the number of months respondents reported earning at each rate. Regular and irregular yearly income was totaled by individual, and then by household to get the final yearly estimate.
• Livestock Income, Past m (PPP$)
Annual profits from livestock. Profits are [X] -[Y] where X and Y are the reference numbers for livestock revenue and costs, respectively, defined elsewhere in this document.

• Non-Livestock Income, Past m (PPP$) Annual profits from agriculture, business, and paid labor. Profits are [X] -[Y] where X and Y are the reference numbers for agriculture, business, and paid labor revenue and costs, respectively, defined elsewhere in this document.
• Food Security Index (z-Score)

The food security index is constructed using the following binary variables: no adults have reduced eating or skipped meals in the past year; no adults have adult foregone food for a whole day in the past year; no children have reduced eating or skipped meals in the past year; everyone in the household regularly eats at least two meals a day. All are oriented so that a value of one indicates higher food security, and each is left missing if the question was not answered. Variables are standardized, averaged, and standardized again to create the final index.

• Savings Index (z-Score) Index constructed from total savings amount and total savings deposits in past three months: each variable is standardized using the control group mean and SD, summed and the sum standardized again.

• Perceived Economic Status ( -) Respondent self-ranking of "financial situation these days," on a "ladder" with rungs from from to , where the top is "very comfortable" and the bottom is "extremely poor."
• Housing Index (z-Score)

The housing index is constructed using the following variables: number of rooms per-adultequivalent; has roof primarily of concrete; has walls primarily of stone; has a latrine; has done household repairs in the past m; spending on household repairs; plans to do household repairs; uses treated water; and inverse of time to access water. Each variable is translated into a Z-score, then a Z-score of the components is created to form the final index.
• Debt Index (z-Score)

The debt index is constructed using the following variables: value of informal loans; value of formal loans; and value of debt. Each variable is translated into a Z-score, then a Z-score of the components is created to form the final index.

div.head: Shocks, Household Consumption, Mortality, and Travel (Table )
div.p: • Had Any Shock in Past m Indicator variable for any household shock in the past months, including crime, serious illness / medical expenses, home damage, theft, death of livestock, crop failure, and legal disputes.
• Had Livestock Shock in Past m Indicator variable for any livestock shock (illness or death) in the past months.
• Had Shock and Used Savings to Finance Coping in Past m Indicator variable for use of savings in response to shock, set to zero if there was no shock and missing if shock data are not known.
• Had Shock and Used Loan to Finance Coping in Past m Indicator variable for use of loans in response to shock, set to zero if there was no shock and missing if shock data are not known.

• Had Shock and Used Sale of Livestock or Crops to Finance Coping in Past m Indicator variable for use of asset sale in response to shock, set to zero if there was no shock and missing if shock data are not known.
• Household Size Count of individuals in the household at time of survey

div.head: • Average Household Education (Adults)
div.p: Average years of schooling per adult household member equivalent, where individuals under years old are counted as half an adult equivalent.
• Average Household Age Average age (in years) of permanent household members.
• Household Has New Members Since Baseline Indicator of whether household has new members since baseline.
• Number New Members Since Baseline Number of new household members since baseline.
• New Household Head Since Baseline Indicator of whether household has new head since baseline.

div.head: Baseline
div.p: Demographics (Table )
• Number of Adults (≥ years) Count of individuals years or older in the household at time of survey.
• Number of Children ( years) Count of individuals younger than years in the household at time of survey.
• Household Size Count of individuals in the household at time of survey.
• Average Age of Adult Household Members Average age (in years) of permanent adult household members.
• Average Years of Schooling of Adult Household Members Average years of schooling per adult household member equivalent, where individuals under years old are counted as half an adult equivalent.
• Household Head Age Age (in years) of head of household at time of survey.
• Household Head Age Indicator variable of whether head of household is more than years old at time of survey.
• Household Head Is Female Indicator variable for whether the head of household at the time of survey is female.
• Household Head Years of Schooling Years of schooling for head of household at baseline.
• Household Head Work Impeded by Illness or Disability Indicator variable for disabled head of household at baseline.
